author: chris2_2_2

author: timbeiko
content: I‚Äôm not sure what you mean by that?

author: timbeiko
content: The ‚Äúcost‚Äù this factors is what are the odds that your block gets uncled by adding a marginal transaction, and how much do you lose if that block gets uncled.

author: andi9314
content: The pools that won't update will be just leaving money on the table for other pools to take, right? As long as an enough share of pools update, the average block size won't go down, it will just fluctuate a bit and some pools will make more money.

author: timbeiko
content: Yeah exactly, unless the price is so low it is not worth it for anyone to pick up the txn. I think 1 gwei is probably too low, and last time I checked 2 gwei would make it ‚Äúworth it‚Äù for ~50% of blocks with MEV bundles, and 3 gwei was enough for ~80%

author: chris2_2_2
content: You lose the profit from that mev if your uncled so it assumes that mev is worth xxx. But because mev companies are offering 2-3x more than mev is currently worth to push expansion/adoption then that risk also goes up significantly.

author: timbeiko
content: Sure, obviously if MEV companies are subsiding their transactions at 2-300%, then users will need to compete with that for inclusion, so ~2 gwei becomes ~4 gwei, for example. The general principle is still that you need to set the priority fee to whatever cost makes it worth it for at least some mienrs to pick up the txns, and that mining is competitive so any miner who isn't picking up txns lets the person mining the next block get that revenue.

author: Deleted User
content:
I think there is an argument to be made for smoothing rewards for miners, and a fixed payment rather than highly variable block payments can be attractive. 

That being said, the way to structure that is not by introducing some random shitcoin. EDEN hurts pretty much everybody in the ecosystem, save the biggest MEV extractors. Miners will be worse off, and searchers, save for the biggest ones, will also be worse off.
